newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - August 5.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Ireland - August 5.

text.p: Following are the highlights of the Irish press on Tuesday:
- SDLP leader John Hume is considering standing for the presidency following pressure from the political establishment in Dublin, particularly Fine Gael.
- The RUC has ordered the rerouting of three parades planned for Saturday morning before the traditional Apprentice Boys' parade in Londonderry later that day.
- Heavy rainfall, which led to flooding in the south and disrupted bank holiday travel services, is expected to continue this week.
- Overseas investors continued to sell pounds yesterday ahead of two crucial meetings on interest rates this week.
- All IRA activity in Northern Ireland, including targeting and surveillance, has ceased, the RUC revealed yesterday.
- A 30-year old Irish climber fell 1,200 feet to his death yesterday while climbing Mont Blanc.
- SDLP leader John Hume may yet stand for the presidency, according to the New York Times.

- Finance minister Charlie McCreevy has asked the boards of the two state-owned banks, ICC and ACC, to provide him with a comprehensive range of options regarding their future ownership structure by next month.
- The Irish criminal justice system is set to grind to a halt unless the government acts to pay massive arrears owed to the legal profession.
- The British government will wait until the end of the month before deciding if the IRA cease-fire is genuine, Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam said yesterday.
- Ferry and train services were hit and many driving conditions were dangerous as the bad weather which hit the bank holiday failed to abate.
